title: Living With Yourself review: Double Paul Rudd isn't necessarily double the fun
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Here’s a massive life tip – if you think something is too good to be true, it usually is.

This is something that seems to have slipped by the middle-management and miserable Miles (Paul Rudd) in Living With Yourself.

Offered a rejuvenating spa treatment that has somehow fixed the life of his annoyingly confident co-worker, Miles decides to go for it, draining his bank account for the extreme facility without a second thought for wife Kate (Aisling Bea).

Advertisement

Advertisement

(Another pro-tip – it doesn’t cost $15,000 for a facial)

Cut to a few hours later, and waking up buried alive, it turns out he’s actually undergone a cloning procedure – and when he returns home he discovers he’s been replaced with a newer, nicer, Miles.

Cue the hilarity of Paul Rudd talking to Paul Rudd for eight episodes as he tries to figure out what happened and what to do next.

Paul Rudd took on quite the challenge and it pays off (Picture: Netflix)

Prepare for the slow burn and throw away expectations of any slapstick comedy you think might come with the premise, this is not the series for that.

Paul Rudd (yes we’re going to refer to him by full name at all times) is a likeable person, and obviously carries us through the season playing two of the three main characters, but it’s after the initial gimmick of two Rudds wears thin that problems start emerging.

In the show, it’s who gets to sleep with wife Kate, which one is the clone and which one isn’t, and how they’re going to split the life that, as far as they’re concerned, they’ve both led.

Aisling and Paul’s Miles and Kate are a couple to root for (Picture: Netflix)

It’s a testament to him that you want to keep watching despite the fact that Miles is a massive man-baby and really not that likeable a person, and neither, for that matter, is his wife Kate, who appears to be so desperate for a baby it doesn’t matter how she gets it.

Advertisement

Advertisement

It takes until almost the end of the series for her motivations to have a real reason behind it, and by then you’re almost ready to write her off. But she’s actually great – as is Aisling Bea, who continues to find comedy and light in the hardest of plots and roles.

Living With Yourself takes a while to get going, and the first few episodes are a bit tough to get through, only really picking up around the end of episode three.

More: Netflix Matt Bomer hides sinister secret after killer car crash in first trailer for The Sinner 3 Best vegan documentaries to stream on Netflix as The Game Changers launches Aaron Paul admits Breaking Bad: El Camino's alternative ending revealed Brock's letter

But if you hang in there, it’s a simmering funny tale and a really interesting take on what it means to be flawed. A comedy-drama more than comedy, but the laughs are there. Eventually.

Living With Yourself is available now on Netflix.

description: Aisiling Bea gets two Paul Rudds to play with in Living With Yourself - and the results are great, once they get there.
